explanation:
Agent A’s scenario describes process_value being called with start_value==end_value==NULL for a key with no value (e.g. "key&"). That can happen: PP_Callback is entered without having set start_value/end_value, so post_process_urlencoded will pass those NULLs through to process_value. However, MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is about calls to the <string.h> functions that themselves might access out-of-bounds memory. The code in post_process_urlencoded does not itself call any <string.h> function on those (possibly NULL) value pointers; the only uses of string.h in this function are memcpy calls that are guarded by a non-zero key_len and by buffer bounds checks. When key_len != 0, the logic and invariants ensure start_key points into post_data, so the memcpy source is valid. Whether calling process_value with NULL pointers leads to a Rule 21.17 violation depends on process_value’s implementation — if process_value were to call strlen/memcpy/etc. on a NULL or otherwise invalid pointer without checking, the violation would be in process_value, not in post_process_urlencoded. (As an aside: pointer-subtraction end_key - start_key when both are NULL would be undefined behavior by the C standard, but that is a different concern/rule than MISRA 21.17.)

Therefore the report that post_process_urlencoded itself violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is not correct; any violation would reside in process_value if it misuses the received pointers.
